revision.text:
{{Other uses}} [[File:The_High_Rollers_Extravaganza_Co._-_Bend_Her_-_c.1900.jpg|thumb|300px|Burlesque on ''[[Ben-Hur: A Tale of the Christ|Ben-Hur]]'', c. 1900]] A '''burlesque''' is a literary, dramatic or musical work intended to cause laughter by caricaturing the manner or spirit of serious works, or by ludicrous treatment of their subjects.<ref name=oed>[http://www.oed.com/view/Entry/24999 "Burlesque",] ''Oxford English Dictionary'', Oxford University Press, accessed 16 February 2011 {{subscription}}</ref> The word derives from the Italian ''{{wiktita|burlesco}}'', which, in turn, is derived from the Italian ''{{wiktita|burla}}'' – a joke, ridicule or mockery.<ref>In theatrical use, a burla was "a comic interlude or practical joke introduced, usually extempore, into a performance by the servant masks of the [[commedia dell'arte]] … developed at will into a small independent 'turn', the characters returning at its conclusion to the main theme of the plot". See Hartnoll, Phyllis and Peter Found. [http://www.oxfordreference.com/views/ENTRY.html?subview=Main&entry=t79.e492 "Burla",] ''The Concise Oxford Companion to the Theatre'', Oxford University Press, 1996. Oxford Reference Online, accessed 16 February 2011 {{subscription}}</ref><ref>[https://www.myheritage.com/research/record-90100-43624043/the-new-york-clipper-vol-62-september#fullscreen "Burlesque News – The Growth of Burlesque"], ''[[New York Clipper]]'', Vol. 62, No. 31, September 12, 1914, p. 18 (accessed February 28, 2017, ''via'' [[MyHeritage]])</ref>
Burlesque overlaps in meaning with [[caricature]], [[parody]] and travesty, and, in its theatrical sense, with [[extravaganza]], as presented during the [[Victorian burlesque|Victorian era]].<ref>[[H. W. Fowler|Fowler, H. W.]], rev. [[Ernest Gowers|Sir Ernest Gowers]] (1965). ''Modern English Usage''. Oxford: Oxford University Press, pp. 68 and 96</ref> "Burlesque" has been used in English in this literary and theatrical sense since the late 17th century. It has been applied retrospectively to works of [[Geoffrey Chaucer|Chaucer]] and [[William Shakespeare|Shakespeare]] and to the Graeco-Roman classics.<ref name=Baldick>Baldick, Chris. [http://www.oxfordreference.com/views/ENTRY.html?subview=Main&entry=t56.e153 "Burlesque",] ''The Oxford Dictionary of Literary Terms'', Oxford University Press, 2008. Oxford Reference Online. Oxford University Press, accessed 16 February 2011 {{subscription}}</ref> Contrasting examples of literary burlesque are [[Alexander Pope]]'s ''[[The Rape of the Lock]]'' and [[Samuel Butler (poet)|Samuel Butler]]'s ''[[Hudibras]]''. An example of musical burlesque is [[Richard Strauss]]'s 1890 [[Burleske|Burleske for piano and orchestra]]. Examples of [[Victorian burlesque|theatrical burlesques]] include [[W. S. Gilbert]]'s ''[[Robert the Devil (Gilbert)|Robert the Devil]]'' and the [[A. C. Torr]] – [[Meyer Lutz]] shows, including ''[[Ruy Blas and the Blase Roue|Ruy Blas and the Blasé Roué]]''.
A later use of the term, [[American burlesque|particularly in the United States]], refers to performances in a [[variety show]] format. These were popular from the 1860s to the 1940s, often in [[cabaret]]s and clubs, as well as theatres, and featured bawdy comedy and female [[striptease]]. Some Hollywood films attempted to recreate the spirit of these performances from the 1930s to the 1960s, or included burlesque-style scenes within dramatic films, such as 1972's ''[[Cabaret (1972 film)|Cabaret]]'' and 1979's ''[[All That Jazz (film)|All That Jazz]]'', among others. There has been a resurgence of interest in this format since the 1990s.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Sankar-Gorton|first1=Eliza|title=Burlesque Is Back and Here Is What You Need to Know About It|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/eliza-sankargorton/burlesque-is-back-and-here-is-what-you-need-to-know-about-it_b_7176112.html| website=www.huffingtonpost.com|publisher=[[The Huffington Post]]|date=30 April 2015|accessdate=7 May 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web| last1=Petkovic| first1=John| title=Burlesque: Then and now, a timeline of performers from Lili St. Cyr to Dita VonTeese|url=http://www.cleveland.com/entertainment/index.ssf/2010/11/burlesque_then_and_now_a_timel.html|website=www.cleveland.com|publisher=[[The Plain Dealer]]|date=28 November 2010|accessdate=7 May 2015}}</ref>
==Literary origins and development== [[File:Arabella-Fermor-crop.jpg|thumb|left|upright|Arabella Fermor, target of ''[[The Rape of the Lock]]'']] The word first appears in a title in [[Francesco Berni]]'s ''Opere burlesche'' of the early 16th century, works that had circulated widely in manuscript before they were printed. For a time, burlesque verses were known as ''poesie bernesca'' in his honour. 'Burlesque' as a literary term became widespread in 17th century Italy and France, and subsequently England, where it referred to a grotesque imitation of the dignified or pathetic.<ref name="Grove">Fredric Woodbridge Wilson: "Burlesque", ''Grove Music Online'' ed. L. Macy (Accessed December 04, 2008), [http://www.grovemusic.com (subscription access)]</ref> [[William Shakespeare|Shakespeare]]'s Pyramus and Thisbe scene in ''[[Midsummer Night's Dream]]'' and the general mocking of romance in Beaumont and Fletcher's ''[[The Knight of the Burning Pestle]]'' were early examples of such imitation.<ref name=stanton>Stanton, p. 50</ref>
In 17th century Spain, playwright and poet [[Miguel de Cervantes]] ridiculed medieval romance in his many satirical works. Among Cervantes' works are ''[[Exemplary Novels]]'' and the ''Eight Comedies and Eight New Interludes'' published in 1615.<ref>[https://www.webcitation.org/5kwQTtSRP?url=http://encarta.msn.com/encyclopedia_761570534/burlesque.html Burlesque], ''MSN Encarta'', accessed 18 June 2012</ref> The term burlesque has been applied retrospectively to works of [[Geoffrey Chaucer|Chaucer]] and Shakespeare and to the Graeco-Roman classics.<ref name=Baldick/>
Burlesque was intentionally ridiculous in that it imitated several styles and combined imitations of certain authors and artists with absurd descriptions. In this, the term was often used interchangeably with "[[pastiche]]", "[[parody]]", and the 17th and 18th century genre of the "[[mock-heroic]]".<ref>Sanders, p. 291</ref> Burlesque depended on the reader's (or listener's) knowledge of the subject to make its intended effect, and a high degree of literacy was taken for granted.<ref>Speaight, George. "All froth and bubble", ''[[The Times Literary Supplement]]'', 1 October 1976, p. 1233</ref>
17th and 18th century burlesque was divided into two types: '''High burlesque''' refers to a burlesque imitation where a literary, elevated manner was applied to a commonplace or comically inappropriate subject matter as, for example, in the literary [[Parody#English term|parody]] and the [[mock-heroic]]. One of the most commonly cited examples of high burlesque is [[Alexander Pope]]'s "sly, knowing and courtly" ''[[The Rape of the Lock]]''.<ref>Sanders, pp. 290–91</ref> '''Low burlesque''' applied an irreverent, mocking style to a serious subject; an example is [[Samuel Butler (1612-1680)|Samuel Butler]]'s poem ''[[Hudibras]]'', which described the misadventures of a Puritan knight in satiric [[doggerel]] verse, using a colloquial idiom. Butler's addition to his comic poem of an ethical subtext made his caricatures into [[satire]].<ref>''Hudibras'' was so popular that it became the subject of parody itself. See Sanders, p. 255.</ref>
In more recent times, burlesque true to its literary origins is still performed in [[revue]]s and [[Sketch comedy|sketches]].<ref name=stanton/> [[Tom Stoppard]]'s 1974 play ''[[Travesties]]'' is an example of a full-length play drawing on the burlesque tradition.<ref>Stanton, p. 50; and Hunter, Jim (1982) ''Tom Stoppard's Plays''. London: Faber and Faber, {{ISBN|0-571-11903-4}}, pp. 23–33, 141–146 and 237–242</ref>
==In music== {{see also|Parody music}}
===Classical music=== Beginning in the early 18th century, the term burlesque was used throughout Europe to describe musical works in which serious and comic elements were juxtaposed or combined to achieve a grotesque effect.<ref name=kennedy>[[Michael Kennedy (music critic)|Kennedy, Michael]] (2006), ''The Oxford Dictionary of Music'', p. 134</ref> As derived from literature and theatre, "burlesque" was used, and is still used, in music to indicate a bright or high-spirited mood, sometimes in contrast to seriousness.<ref name=kennedy/>
In this sense of farce and exaggeration rather than parody, it appears frequently on the German-language stage between the middle of the 19th century and the 1920s. Burlesque operettas were written by [[Johann Strauss II]] (''Die lustigen Weiber von Wien'', 1868),<ref>Lamb, Andrew (1992), "Strauss, Johann" in ''The [[New Grove Dictionary of Opera]]'', ed. Stanley Sadie (London) {{ISBN|0-333-73432-7}}</ref> [[Karl Michael Ziehrer|Ziehrer]] (''Mahomed's Paradies'',1866; ''Das Orakel zu Delfi'', 1872; ''Cleopatra, oder Durch drei Jahrtausende'', 1875; ''In fünfzig Jahren'', 1911)<ref>Lamb, Andrew (1992), "Ziehrer, C. M." in ''The [[New Grove Dictionary of Opera]]'', ed. Stanley Sadie (London) {{ISBN|0-333-73432-7}}</ref> and [[Bruno Granichstaedten]] (''Casimirs Himmelfahrt'', 1911). French references to burlesque are less common than German, though [[André Grétry|Grétry]] composed for a "drame burlesque" (''Matroco'', 1777).<ref>Charlton, David and M. Elizabeth C. Bartlet, [http://www.oxfordmusiconline.com/subscriber/article/grove/music/43361 "Grétry, André-Ernest-Modeste: Works,"] ''Grove Music Online''. Oxford Music Online, accessed 24 February 2011 {{subscription}}</ref> [[Igor Stravinsky|Stravinsky]] called his 1916 one-act chamber opera-ballet ''[[Renard (Stravinsky)|Renard]]'' (''The Fox'') a ''"Histoire burlesque chantée et jouée"'' (''burlesque tale sung and played'') and his 1911 ballet ''[[Petrushka (ballet)|Petrushka]]'' a "burlesque in four scenes". A later example is the 1927 burlesque operetta by [[Ernst Krenek]] entitled ''[[Schwergewicht]]'' (''Heavyweight'') (1927). {{listen|filename=Richard_Strauss_-_Neal_O'Doan_-_Burleske.ogg|title=Burleske|description=''[[Burleske]]'' (1885–86), by [[Richard Strauss]]. Performed by Neal O'Doan with the Seattle Philharmonic Orchestra|format=[[ogg]]}} Some orchestral and chamber works have also been designated as burlesques, of which two early examples are the Ouverture-Suite ''Burlesque de Quixotte'', TWV 55, by [[Georg Philipp Telemann|Telemann]] and the Sinfonia Burlesca by [[Leopold Mozart]] (1760). Another often-performed piece is [[Richard Strauss]]'s 1890 [[Burleske|Burleske for piano and orchestra]].<ref name=kennedy/> Other examples include the following: *1901: Six Burlesques, Op. 58 for piano four hands by [[Max Reger]] *1904: Scherzo Burlesque, Op. 2 for piano and orchestra by [[Béla Bartók]] *1911: Three Burlesques, Op. 8c for piano by Bartók *1920: Burlesque for Piano, by [[Arnold Bax]] *1931: Ronde burlesque, Op. 78 for orchestra by [[Florent Schmitt]] *1932: Fantaisie burlesque, for piano by [[Olivier Messiaen]] *1956: Burlesque for Piano and Chamber Orchestra, Op. 13g by [[Bertold Hummel]] *1982: Burlesque for Wind Quintet, Op. 76b by Hummel
Burlesque can be used to describe particular movements of instrumental musical compositions, often involving dance rhythms. Examples are the Burlesca, in [[Partitas, BWV 825-830|Partita No. 3 for keyboard (BWV 827)]] by [[Johann Sebastian Bach|Bach]], the "Rondo-Burleske" third movement of [[Symphony No. 9 (Mahler)|Symphony No. 9]] by [[Gustav Mahler|Mahler]], and the "Burlesque" fourth movement of [[Violin Concerto No. 1 (Shostakovich)|Shostakovich's Violin Concerto No. 1]].<ref>McGregor, Andrew, [https://www.bbc.co.uk/music/reviews/mmzf "Dmitri Shostakovich Violin Concertos 1 & 2 Review"], BBC Music, accessed 24 February 2011</ref>
===Jazz=== The use of burlesque has not been confined to classical music. Well known [[ragtime]] travesties include ''The Russian Rag'', by [[George L. Cobb]], which is based on [[Rachmaninoff]]'s [[Prelude in C-sharp minor (Rachmaninoff)|Prelude in C-sharp minor]], and [[Harry L. Alford|Harry Alford]]'s ''Lucy's Sextette'' based on the [[sextet]], 'Chi mi frena in tal momento?', from ''[[Lucia di Lammermoor]]'' by [[Donizetti]].<ref>Harrison, Max (2006): ''Rachmaninoff: Life, Works, Recordings'' p 229</ref>
==Victorian theatrical burlesque== [[File:Florence St. John.jpg|thumb|150px|[[Florence St. John]] in ''[[Carmen up to Data]]'']] {{main|Victorian burlesque}} Victorian burlesque, sometimes known as "travesty" or "[[extravaganza]]",<ref>According to the ''[[Grove Dictionary of Music and Musicians]]'', "the various genre terms were always applied freely", and by the 1860s their use had become "arbitrary and capricious": see [http://www.oxfordmusiconline.com/subscriber/article/grove/music/04381 "Burlesque,"] ''Grove Music Online''. Oxford Music Online, accessed 3 February 2011 {{subscription}}. In an 1896 article on Burlesque in ''The Theatre'', the three terms are used interchangeably: see Adams, W. Davenport. "Burlesque: Old ''v.'' New", ''The Theatre'', 1 March 1896, pp. 144–45</ref> was popular in London theatres between the 1830s and the 1890s. It took the form of [[parody music|musical theatre parody]] in which a well-known opera, play or ballet was adapted into a broad comic play, usually a musical play, often risqué in style, mocking the theatrical and musical conventions and styles of the original work, and quoting or [[pastiche|pastiching]] text or music from the original work. The comedy often stemmed from the incongruity and absurdity of the classical subjects, with realistic historical dress and settings, being juxtaposed with the modern activities portrayed by the actors. [[Lucia Elizabeth Vestris|Madame Vestris]] produced burlesques at the [[Olympic Theatre]] beginning in 1831 with ''Olympic Revels'' by [[J. R. Planché]].<ref>Adams, W. Davenport. ''A Book of Burlesque'' (London: Henry and Co., 1891), p. 44</ref> Other authors of burlesques included [[H. J. Byron]], [[G. R. Sims]], [[F. C. Burnand]], [[W. S. Gilbert]] and [[Fred Leslie]].<ref name=times70/>
Victorian burlesque related to and in part derived from traditional English [[pantomime]] "with the addition of gags and 'turns'."<ref name=grove>[[Erich Schwandt|Schwandt, Erich]] et al. [http://www.oxfordmusiconline.com/subscriber/article/grove/music/04381 "Burlesque",] ''Grove Music Online''. Oxford Music Online, accessed 3 February 2011 {{subscription}}</ref> In the early burlesques, following the example of [[ballad opera]], the words of the songs were written to popular music;<ref>Moss, Harold Gene. [https://www.jstor.org/stable/830406 "Popular Music and the Ballad Opera",] ''Journal of the American Musicological Society'', Vol. 26, No. 3 (Autumn, 1973), pp. 365–82, University of California Press, accessed 2 February 2011 {{subscription}}</ref> later burlesques mixed the music of [[opera]], [[operetta]], [[music hall]] and [[revue]], and some of the more ambitious shows had original music composed for them. This English style of burlesque was successfully introduced to New York in the 1840s.<ref>Rogers, Delmer D. [https://www.jstor.org/stable/779924 "Public Music Performances in New York City from 1800 to 1850",] ''Anuario Interamericano de Investigacion Musical'', Vol. 6 (1970), pp. 5–50, accessed 2 February 2011 {{subscription}}</ref>
[[File:Faustupto.jpg|thumb|150px|Sheet music from ''[[Faust up to Date]]''|left]] Some of the most frequent subjects for burlesque were the plays of Shakespeare and grand opera.<ref name=marvin>Marvin, Roberta Montemorra. [https://www.jstor.org/stable/3878318 "Verdian Opera Burlesqued: A Glimpse into Mid-Victorian Theatrical Culture",] ''Cambridge Opera Journal'', Vol. 15, No. 1 (March 2003), pp. 33–66, Cambridge University Press, accessed 2 February 2011 {{subscription}}</ref><ref name=wells>Wells, Stanley. [https://www.jstor.org/stable/2867735 "Shakespearian Burlesques",] ''Shakespeare Quarterly'', Vol. 16, No. 1 (Winter, 1965), pp. 49–61, Folger Shakespeare Library in association with George Washington University, accessed 2 February 2011 {{subscription}}</ref> The dialogue was generally written in rhyming couplets, liberally peppered with bad [[pun]]s.<ref name=grove/> A typical example from a burlesque of ''[[Macbeth]]'': Macbeth and Banquo enter under an umbrella, and the witches greet them with "Hail! hail! hail!" Macbeth asks Banquo, "What mean these salutations, noble thane?" and is told, "These showers of 'Hail' anticipate your 'reign'".<ref name=wells/> A staple of burlesque was the display of attractive women in [[Breeches role|travesty roles]], dressed in tights to show off their legs, but the plays themselves were seldom more than modestly risqué.<ref name=grove/>
[[File:Ruy-blas-programme-crop.jpg|right|thumb|150px|[[Souvenir programme|Programme]]: ''[[Ruy Blas and the Blase Roue|Ruy Blas and the Blasé Roué]]'']] Burlesque became the speciality of certain London theatres, including the [[Gaiety Theatre, London|Gaiety]] and [[Royal Strand Theatre]] from the 1860s to the early 1890s. Until the 1870s, burlesques were often one-act pieces running less than an hour and using [[pastiche]]s and parodies of popular songs, opera [[aria]]s and other music that the audience would readily recognize. The house stars included [[Nellie Farren]], [[John D'Auban]], [[Edward O'Connor Terry|Edward Terry]] and [[Fred Leslie]].<ref name=times70>"Theatrical Humour in the Seventies", ''[[The Times]]'', 20 February 1914, p. 9</ref><ref name=Timesobit>"Mr. D'Auban's 'Startrap' Jumps". ''The Times'', 17 April 1922, p. 17</ref> From about 1880, Victorian burlesques grew longer, until they were a whole evening's entertainment rather than part of a double- or triple-bill.<ref name=times70/> In the early 1890s, these burlesques went out of fashion in London, and the focus of the Gaiety and other burlesque theatres changed to the new more wholesome but less literary genre of [[Edwardian musical comedy]].<ref>Gänzl, Kurt. [http://www.oxforddnb.com/view/article/38669 "Edwardes, George Joseph (1855–1915)",] ''Oxford Dictionary of National Biography'', Oxford University Press, 2004, accessed 3 February 2011 {{subscription}}</ref>
==American burlesque== [[File:Bon-Ton Burlesquers2.jpg|thumb|upright=0.7|left|Advertisement for a burlesque troupe, 1898]] {{main|American burlesque}} American burlesque shows were originally an offshoot of Victorian burlesque. The English genre had been successfully staged in New York from the 1840s, and it was popularised by a visiting British burlesque troupe, [[Lydia Thompson]] and the "British Blondes", beginning in 1868.<ref name=Friends>Hoffos, Signe and Moulder, Bob. [http://www.kensalgreen.co.uk/documents/FOKGC43_Thompson.pdf "Desperately Seeking Lydia" and "Appreciating Lydia",] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110513080257/http://www.kensalgreen.co.uk/documents/FOKGC43_Thompson.pdf |date=2011-05-13 }} ''The Friends of Kensal Green Cemetery Magazine'', Vol. 43, Autumn 2006, pp. 1–7</ref> New York burlesque shows soon incorporated elements and the structure of the popular [[minstrel show]]s. They consisted of three parts: first, songs and ribald comic sketches by low comedians; second, assorted [[Olio (musical number)|olios]] and male acts, such as acrobats, magicians and solo singers; and third, chorus numbers and sometimes a burlesque in the English style on politics or a current play. The entertainment was usually concluded by an exotic dancer or a wrestling or boxing match.<ref name=britannica>[http://library.eb.co.uk/eb/article-9018177 "Burlesque show",] ''Encyclopædia Britannica'', Online Library Edition, accessed 16 February 2011 {{subscription}}</ref>
While burlesque went out of fashion in England towards the end of the 19th century, to be replaced by [[Edwardian musical comedy]], the American style of burlesque flourished, but with increasing focus on female nudity. Exotic "cooch" dances were brought in, ostensibly Syrian in origin. The entertainments were given in clubs and cabarets, as well as music halls and theatres. By the early 20th century, there were two national circuits of burlesque shows competing with the [[vaudeville]] circuit, as well as resident companies in New York, such as [[Minsky's Burlesque|Minsky's]] at the Winter Garden.<ref name=britannica/>
[[File:Gypsy Rose Lee NYWTS 1.jpg|thumb|upright=0.7|[[Gypsy Rose Lee]]]] The transition from burlesque on the old lines to striptease was gradual. At first, [[soubrette]]s showed off their figures while singing and dancing; some were less active but compensated by appearing in elaborate stage costumes.<ref name=humez>Humez, Nick. [http://go.galegroup.com/ps/i.do?&id=GALE%7CCX3409000367&v=2.1&u=wes_ttda&it=r&p=GVRL&sw=w "Burlesque".] ''St. James Encyclopedia of Popular Culture'', ed. Sara Pendergast and Tom Pendergast, Gale Virtual Reference Library, accessed 16 February 2011 {{subscription}}</ref> The strippers gradually supplanted the singing and dancing soubrettes; by 1932 there were at least 150 strip principals in the US.<ref name=humez/> Star strippers included [[Sally Rand]], [[Gypsy Rose Lee]], [[Tempest Storm]], [[Lili St. Cyr]], [[Blaze Starr]], [[Ann Corio]] and [[Margie Hart]], who was celebrated enough to be mentioned in song lyrics by [[Lorenz Hart]] and [[Cole Porter]].<ref name=humez/> By the late 1930s, burlesque shows would have up to six strippers supported by one or two comics and a master of ceremonies. Comics who appeared in burlesque early in their careers included [[Fanny Brice]], [[Mae West]], [[Eddie Cantor]], [[Abbott and Costello]], [[W. C. Fields]], [[Jackie Gleason]], [[Danny Thomas]], [[Al Jolson]], [[Bert Lahr]], [[Phil Silvers]], [[Sid Caesar]], [[Danny Kaye]], [[Red Skelton]] and [[Sophie Tucker]].<ref name=humez/>
[[File:MichelleLAmourFanDance2641.jpg|thumb|left|upright=0.7|[[Michelle L'amour]], 2005 [[Miss Exotic World Pageant|Miss Exotic World]]]] The uninhibited atmosphere of burlesque establishments owed much to the free flow of alcoholic liquor, and the enforcement of [[Prohibition]] was a serious blow.<ref>Hartnoll, Phyllis and Peter Found. [http://www.oxfordreference.com/views/ENTRY.html?subview=Main&entry=t79.e493 "Burlesque, American",] ''The Concise Oxford Companion to the Theatre'', Oxford University Press, 1996. Oxford Reference Online, accessed 16 February 2011 {{subscription}}</ref> In New York, Mayor [[Fiorello H. La Guardia]] clamped down on burlesque, effectively putting it out of business by the early 1940s.<ref name=NYT/> It lingered on elsewhere in the U.S., increasingly neglected, and by the 1970s, with nudity commonplace in theatres, reached "its final shabby demise."<ref>Allen, p. xi</ref> Both during its declining years and afterwards there have been films that sought to capture American burlesque, including ''[[Lady of Burlesque]]'' (1943),<ref>"New Films In London", ''The Times'', 2 August 1943, p. 8</ref> ''[[Striporama]]'' (1953),<ref>[https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0047535/ ''Striporama''] Internet Movie Database, accessed 17 February 2011</ref> and ''[[The Night They Raided Minsky's]]'' (1968).<ref>Slonimsky, Nicholas, [http://glnd.alexanderstreet.com/search/fulltext/Burlesque "Burlesque show",] ''Baker's Dictionary of Music'', Schirmer Reference, New York, 1997, accessed 16 February 2010 {{subscription}}</ref> [[File:Stage Door Johnnies.jpg|thumb|upright=1.1|The "Stage Door Johnnies" performing at the Burlesque Hall of Fame in Las Vegas, 2011]]
In recent decades, there has been a revival of burlesque, sometimes called [[Neo-Burlesque]],<ref name=NYT>Caldwell, Mark. [https://www.nytimes.com/2008/05/18/nyregion/thecity/18burl.html "The Almost Naked City",] ''[[The New York Times]]'', 18 May 2008, accessed 19 September 2009</ref> on both sides of the Atlantic.<ref name=tws2E35>Newman, Martin. [https://www.mirror.co.uk/lifestyle/going-out/music/burlesque-and-cabaret-a-la-dita-von-690650 "Burlesque ventures out of the West End and into... Camden Town"], ''The Mirror'', 18 February 2012</ref> A new generation, nostalgic for the spectacle and perceived glamour of the classic American burlesque, developed a cult following for the art in the early 1990s at Billie Madley's "Cinema" and later at the "Dutch Weismann's Follies" revues in New York City, "The Velvet Hammer" troupe in Los Angeles and The Shim-Shamettes in New Orleans. Ivan Kane's Royal Jelly Burlesque Nightclub at [[Revel Atlantic City]] opened in 2012.<ref>Oliverie, Kristin. [http://www.thedailymeal.com/burlesque-word-atlantic-city-s-revel "Burlesque Is the Word at Atlantic City’s Revel"], ''The Daily Meal'', accessed 18 June 2012</ref> Notable Neo-burlesque performers include [[Dita Von Teese]], and [[Julie Atlas Muz]] and [[Agitprop]] groups like [[Cabaret Red Light]] incorporated political satire and performance art into their burlesque shows. Annual conventions such as the [[Vancouver International Burlesque Festival]] and the [[Miss Exotic World Pageant]] are held.<ref>Sohn, Amy. ''Teasy Does It'', [http://newyorkmetro.com/nymetro/nightlife/sex/columns/nakedcity/9210/ New York Magazine] {{webarchive| url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080720001802/http://newyorkmetro.com/nymetro/nightlife/sex/columns/nakedcity/9210/ |date=2008-07-20 }}, 21 May 2005, accessed 24 February 2011</ref><ref>Clodfelter, Tim. [http://www2.journalnow.com/content/2008/jan/31/this-aint-your-granddads-burlesque-but-he-sure-wou/ "This ain't your granddad's burlesque – but he sure wouldn't mind watching"] {{webarchive| url=https://archive.is/20091007195534/http://www2.journalnow.com/content/2008/jan/31/this-aint-your-granddads-burlesque-but-he-sure-wou/ |date=2009-10-07 }}. ''Winston-Salem Journal'', 31 January 2008, accessed 24 February 2011</ref>

{{Other uses|Case file (disambiguation)}} {{Italic title}} {{Use dmy dates|date=March 2018}} {{Use Australian English|date=March 2018}} {{infobox podcast | title = Casefile (True Crime Podcast) | image = | hosting = "Anonymous host" | production = Mike Migas | editor = | opentheme = | theme_music_composer = Mike Migas, Andrew Joslyn | language = English | website = {{official|http://casefilepodcast.com/}} | audio format = Podcast | began = 9 January 2016 | num_seasons = n/a | num_episodes = 100 + updates | runtime = 20-159 minutes(average c.60) | genre = {{Unbulleted list|True crime|Investigative journalism}} | provider = }} '''''Casefile True Crime Podcast''''', or simply '''''Casefile''''', is a weekly (sometimes fortnightly) [[true crime]] themed [[podcast]] that first aired in Australia in January 2016 and hosted by an Australian man who remains anonymous. The series deals with solved or [[Cold case|cold criminal cases]], often related to well-known murders and serial crimes. Many early episodes relate to Australian cases (e.g. [[Port Arthur massacre (Australia)|Port Arthur]] or the [[Snowtown murders]]), although notable crimes from the UK and the USA are increasingly featured,{{Cite news|url=https://www.standard.co.uk/news/uk/casefile-true-crime-podcast-becomes-global-hit-as-it-examines-uks-most-notorious-crimes-a3500716.html|title=Podcast becomes global hit as it examines UK's most notorious crimes|work=Evening Standard|access-date=2018-03-13|language=en-GB}} and cases from Canada, France, Guyana, Iraq, Ireland, Italy, New Zealand, Poland, and Ukraine have also been included. Unlike a number of similar podcasts, the series is scripted and narrative, relying primarily on original police or mass-media documents, eyewitness accounts, and interview or public announcement recordings.{{Cite news|url=https://www.techradar.com/best/the-best-australian-podcasts|title=The best Australian podcasts to listen to right now|work=TechRadar|access-date=2018-03-13|language=en}} Larger and more-complex cases, such as [[Peter Sutcliffe|The Yorkshire Ripper]], [[Moors murders|The Moors Murders]], and [[Original Night Stalker|The East Area Rapist]], have received multiple-week serialised broadcasts, and case updates to previously aired cases are also provided from time to time. The series has been well received, and has won a number of awards since its debut, including Best of 2016 (iTunes). == Production == The podcast first aired on 9 January 2016{{Cite news|url=https://whatpods.com/ama/casefile/|title=AMA with the host of Casefile True Crime|work=WhatPods|access-date=2018-03-13|language=en-US}} and was conceived by an anonymous Australian host who started producing the show in 2015 in his spare room. The host had just had surgery and was listening to a lot of podcasts and true-crime shows (e.g. ''[[The Joe Rogan Experience]]'', ''[[Dan Carlin|Hardcore History]]'', ''[[Serial (podcast)|Serial]]'' and ''[[Making a Murderer|Making A Murderer]])'' at the time, and was encouraged by [[Joe Rogan]] to make his own based on in-depth research and a storytelling style. According to one source, the host remains anonymous because "he wants the stories, facts, and questions speak for themselves"{{Cite news|url=https://shesaid.com/8-podcasts-binge-youre-obsessed-true-crime/|title=9 Podcasts To Binge If You’re Obsessed With True Crime|date=2018-02-14|work=SHE'SAID'|access-date=2018-03-13|language=en-US}} and "It makes the show about the stories and that's it." According to another review, the podcast's:
deliberately sparse production value became its strongest asset, plunging listeners into a pool of ambient silence with a host neither named nor contextualized. ... the podcast does not go the typical route of parading listeners through a montage of primary source material like evening news reports or interviews with now-wizened investigators; instead, the stories are unfolded slowly and methodically by the anonymous host, with just enough editorializing to make it feel like a friend or a witness is relaying the tale.{{Cite news|url=https://aux.avclub.com/our-favorite-podcasts-of-2016-1798255734|title=Our favorite podcasts of 2016|last=Bulnes|first=Rebecca|work=AUX|access-date=2018-03-13|language=en-US}}
In its current format, the 2018 ''Casefile'' team now consists of two researcher/writers, two composers, a designer, and the host/narrator.{{Cite news|url=http://casefilepodcast.com/team/|title=Team - Casefile: True Crime Podcast|work=Casefile: True Crime Podcast|access-date=2018-03-13|language=en-US}} It has also had a producer, Mike Migas, “since about episode 7”, which led to episodes 1–6 being reworked. Researchers have also travelled internationally to access primary resources in some cases, such as former researcher and co-writer Anna Priestland, who travelled from Melbourne to visit the [[The National Archives (United Kingdom)|national archives]] in [[Kew]] in 2017 to examine police files on [[Myra Hindley]]. A number of the more recent international cases have also been written and researched by the Australian author [[Eileen Ormsby]]. Each case includes a corresponding page on the podcast's official homepage, which details information such as special thank yous, official support phone numbers and websites (for Australia, the UK, the US, Canada and New Zealand), other credits, and resources (such as books, websites, videos, documents, articles, maps, wanted posters, and suspect sketches), as [http://casefilepodcast.com/case-53-east-area-rapist-1976-part-1/ in this example]. Warnings are regularly given at the start of podcasts due to the graphic content. It is available via numerous sites.{{Cite web|url=https://audioboom.com/channel/casefile-true-crime|title=Casefile True Crime|website=audioboom.com|language=en|access-date=2018-03-19}} One episode, Case 55 (Simone Strobel, released 15 July 2017), has been removed due to legal issues, although general details of the case itself are publicly available.{{Cite web|url=http://www.abc.net.au/local/stories/2007/07/09/1973895.htm|title=Inquest hears Strobel boyfriend suspected in death|date=2007-07-09|website=www.abc.net.au|language=en-AU|access-date=2018-03-14}}{{Cite news|url=http://www.news.com.au/national/courts-law/police-study-luxury-beachside-life-of-man-whose-girlfriends-body-was-found-covered-in-palm-fronds/news-story/180de49076f1ca7c1e4249375d0a8dcb|title=Toby Moran’s life under scrutiny by police 12 years after his girlfriend’s mysterious death|work=NewsComAu|access-date=2018-03-14}}{{Cite web|url=https://www.podchaser.com/podcasts/casefile-true-crime-44949/episodes/case-55-simone-strobel-19346758|title=Case 55: Simone Strobel by Casefile True Crime on Podchaser|website=Podchaser|language=en-US|access-date=2018-03-14}} == Episodes == (Note: release dates are based on the official website.) === 2016 === {| class="wikitable sortable" !Case !Title !Date !Notes |- |01 |[[Wanda Beach Murders|The Wanda Beach Murders]] |09 January | |- |02 |[[Tamam Shud case|The Somerton Man]] |16 January | |- |03 |[[Murders of Lauria Bible and Ashley Freeman|Lauria Bible and Ashley Freeman]] |23 January |Update - Part 3 - 23 September |- |61 |[[Lin family murders|The Lin Family]] |30 September | |- |62 |[[Honolulu Strangler|The Honolulu Strangler]] |07 October | |- |63 |Catherine Holmes and Georgina Watmore |14 October | |- |64 |[[List of kidnappings#1950-1979|Peter Weinberger]] |28 October | |- |65 |[[Murder of Allison Baden-Clay|Allison Baden-Clay]] |04 November | |- |66 |[[Blanche Taylor Moore|The Black Widow]] |11 November | |- |67 |[[Battle of Alcatraz|The Battle of Alcatraz]] |18 November | |- |68 |[[June 1962 Alcatraz escape attempt|Escape from Alcatraz]] |25 November | |- |69 |Gary Patterson |02 December | |- |70 |[[Joseph Schwab|The Kimberley Killer]] |09 December | |- |71 |Elodie Morel |16 December | |- |} === 2018 === {| class="wikitable sortable" !Case !Title !Date !Notes |- |72 |[[Wanda Beach Murders#Possible linked cases|Wilhelmina Kruger and Anna Dowlingkoa]] |13 January | |- |73 |The Lady in the Barrel |17 January | |- |74 |Eric Coy |20 January | |- |75 |[[Graeme Thorne kidnapping|Graeme Thorne]] |27 January | |- |76 |[[Silk Road (marketplace)|Silk Road]] |10 February |Part 2 - 17 February
Part 3 - 24 February |- |77 |[[Mia Zapata]] |11 March | |- |78 |[[Mahmudiyah rape and killings|The Janabi Family]] |17 March | |- |79 |Rayna Rison |25 March | |- |80 |Beth Barnard |08 April |Bonus Interview - 11 April |- |81 |[[Murder of Brian Wells|Brian Wells]] |15 April | |- |82 |[[Maria Korp]] |22 April | |- |83 |Chantelle and Leela McDougall, Tony Popic |06 May | |- |84 |[[Murder of Lesley Molseed|Lesley Molseed]] |12 May |Part 2 - 19 May |- |85 |Tom Brown |03 June | |- |86 |Amy Allwine |09 June | |- |87 |[[Murder of Elaine O'Hara|Elaine O'Hara]] |16 June | |- |88 |[[Death of Stephen Hilder|Stephen Hilder]] |07 July | |- |89 |Ella Tundra |14 July | |- |90 |[[Hoddle Street massacre|Hoddle Street]] |28 July | |- |91 |[[Murder of Carly Ryan|Carly Ryan]] |04 August | |- |92 |[[Dnepropetrovsk maniacs|Dnepropetrovsk Maniacs]] |11 August | |- |93 |[[Stella Nickell|Susan Snow and Bruce Nickell]] |25 August | |- |94 |[[Lawrence Horn|Millie & Trevor Horn, Janice Saunders]] |01 September | |- |95 |[[Karol Kot|The Vampire of Krakow]] |08 September | |- |96 |[[David Parker Ray|The Toy Box]] |22 September |Part 2 - 29 September
Part 3 - 6 October |- |97 |[[Rebecca Schaeffer]] |20 October | |- |98 |[[John Leonard Orr|The Pillow Pyro]] |27 October | |- |99 |[[Murder of Becky Watts|Becky Watts]] |10 November | |- |100 |[[Disappearance of the Beaumont children|The Beaumont Children]] |17 November | |- |101 |[[Murder of Sian Kingi|Sian Kingi]] |24 November | |- |102 |Britt Lapthorne |01 December | |} == Reception == Along with the recent rise in true crime podcasting, as seen in [[Serial (podcast)|Serial]] or [[S-Town]], the series has been reviewed positively by several sources:{{Cite news|url=http://www.lbc.co.uk/radio/the-12-best-true-crime-podcasts-of-2018/|title=The 12 Best True Crime Podcasts Of 2018|work=LBC|access-date=2018-03-19|language=en}}{{Cite web|url=https://pickle.nine.com.au/2018/01/25/12/53/casefile-true-crime-podcast-qanda|title=Casefile: True Crime Podcast creator reveals story behind popular series|website=pickle.nine.com.au|language=en-AU|access-date=2018-03-19}} ''[[Rolling Stone]]'' (22 July 2016):
As ''Casefile'' points out in their tagline, fact is scarier than fiction. But what the podcast might really prove is that fact is ''even scarier'' when told in a thick Australian accent – especially when accompanied by ambient, pulsing noise from a trio of professional sound designers and musicians. In each weekly episode, which can run anywhere from 20 minutes to an hour and a half, the narrator... calmly tells a story of a devastating Australian crime. The podcast expertly covers murder and abduction, sometimes walking the listener through the criminal's trial, and other times discussing potential theories for a crime whose perpetrator was never caught.{{Cite web|url=https://www.rollingstone.com/culture/lists/beyond-serial-10-true-crime-podcasts-you-need-to-follow-w429955/casefile-w429962|title=Beyond 'Serial': 10 True Crime Podcasts You Need to Follow|website=Rolling Stone|access-date=2018-03-13}}
[[London Evening Standard|''Evening Standard'']] (28 March 2017):
The Australian-made show, which launched in January last year, has regularly featured in the UK’s top 10 podcasts on iTunes in recent months. It also regularly reaches the top 50 in the US chart, rising as high as fourth last July. ... Its mini-series on Yorkshire Ripper Peter Sutcliffe received 5.8 million downloads — the most for a single case since the launch. Its most popular single episode was on British tourist Peter Falconio ... [which] has more than 4.2 million downloads. A series covering the Moors Murders ... had more than a million downloads in four days.
Download statistics by iTunesChart.net state that Casefile has charted in the top 100 in 4 regions, with peak ranking positions of the podcast including: Australia (1), Canada (9), United Kingdom (14), and United States (7).{{Cite web|url=http://www.itunescharts.net/artists/podcast/casefile-true-crime/podcasts/casefile-true-crime/|title=iTunesCharts.net: 'Casefile True Crime' by Casefile True Crime (International iTunes Chart Performance)|website=www.itunescharts.net|language=en|access-date=2018-08-23}} In Australia, the podcast has consistently been in the top 10 since May 2016.{{Cite web|url=http://www.itunescharts.net/aus/artists/podcast/casefile-true-crime/podcasts/casefile-true-crime/|title=iTunesCharts.net: 'Casefile True Crime' by Casefile True Crime (Australian Podcasts iTunes Chart)|website=www.itunescharts.net|language=en|access-date=2018-08-23}} == Awards == * Best of 2016 (iTunes){{Cite web|url=http://casefilepodcast.com/|title=Welcome to Casefile: True Crime Podcast|website=Casefile: True Crime Podcast|language=en-US|access-date=2018-03-19}} * CastAway 2017 Australian Podcast Awards * Discover Pods award (Most Innovative Podcast 2017){{Cite news|url=http://discoverpods.com/2017-discover-pods-awards-winners/|title=The 2017 Discover Pods Awards Winners {{!}} Discover the Best Podcasts {{!}} Discover Pods|date=2017-12-15|work=Discover the Best Podcasts {{!}} Discover Pods|access-date=2018-03-13|language=en-US}} * Off the Charts 2017 ==See also== *[[Serial (podcast)]] *[[Criminal (podcast)]] == References == {{Reflist}} == External links == *[http://casefilepodcast.com Official website] {{DEFAULTSORT:Casefile, True Crime Podcast}} [[Category:Crime podcasts]] [[Category:Infotainment]] [[Category:Audio podcasts]] [[Category:English-language podcasts]] [[Category:2016 podcast debuts]] [[Category:Scripted podcasts]] [[Category:Investigative journalism]] [[Category:Australian podcasters]]

revision.comment: Guettarda moved page [[Casino/temp]] to [[Casino]] over a redirect without leaving a redirect: too big
revision.text:
{{redirect-distinguish|Gambling house|Gambling House (film)}} {{About|establishments for gambling}} [[File:Las Vegas Strip.png|thumb|right|upright=1.35|The [[Las Vegas Strip]] is renowned for its high concentration of casino resort hotels]] A '''casino''' is a facility which houses and accommodates certain types of [[gambling]] activities. The industry that deals in casinos is called the '''gaming industry'''. Casinos are most commonly built near or combined with hotels, restaurants, retail shopping, cruise ships or other tourist attractions. There is much debate over whether the social and economic consequences of casino gambling outweigh the initial revenue that may be generated.[https://www.nytimes.com/roomfordebate/2010/07/29/should-internet-gambling-be-legalized "Should Internet Gambling Be Legalized?"] (July 29, 2010). ''[New York Times]'', Retrieved 7/20/2011. Some casinos are also known for hosting live entertainment events, such as stand-up comedy, concerts, and sporting events. ==Etymology and usage== The term "casino" is a confusing linguistic [[false friend]] for translators. ''Casino'' is of [[Italian language|Italian origin]]; the root ''casa'' means a house. The term casino may mean a small country [[villa]], [[Summerhouse (building)|summerhouse]], or [[social club]].{{cite book|last1=Thompson|first1=William N.|title=Gambling in America: An Encyclopedia of History, Issues, and Society|date=2015|page=43|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=QAI9BgAAQBAJ&pg=PA43&lpg=PA43&dq=casino+word+italian+casa+villa&source=bl&ots=DDO0I9XXek&sig=eaYdPaCRmSGLtEQYWSDD6XzjeGA&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0CDwQ6AEwB2oVChMIk8LsiYaxxwIVgowNCh2yOwsl#v=onepage&q=casino%20word%20italian%20casa%20villa&f=false|accessdate=August 17, 2015}} During the 19th century, the term ''casino'' came to include other public buildings where pleasurable activities took place; such edifices were usually built on the grounds of a larger Italian villa or [[palazzo]], and were used to host civic town functions, including dancing, gambling, music listening, and sports; examples in Italy include [[Villa Farnese]] and [[Villa Giulia]], and in the US the [[Newport Casino]] in [[Newport, Rhode Island]]. In modern-day Italian a ''casino'' is either a brothel (also called ''casa chiusa'', literally "closed house"), a [[mess]], or a noisy environment, while a gaming house is spelt ''casinò'', with an accent.{{cite web |url=http://dictionary.oed.com/cgi/entry/50034083?single=1&query_type=word&queryword=casino&first=1&max_to_show=10 |title=Casino }}{{cite book|last1=Preble, Rossi|first1=Keith, Francesco|title=Il vero italiano: Your Guide To Speaking "Real" Italian|date=2014|page=66|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=IDU3BAAAQBAJ&pg=PA66&lpg=PA66&dq=casino+word+italian+noisy&source=bl&ots=J6WEIfn4EI&sig=nSQtoePZAyzyfeaa6vHaIF4Kc0E&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0CD0Q6AEwBWoVChMIgNzOhKyxxwIVDDc-Ch3qSwLA#v=onepage&q=casino%20word%20italian%20noisy&f=false|accessdate=August 17, 2015}} Not all casinos were used for gaming. The [[Catalina Casino]],{{cite web|url=http://avalonball.com/casino.asp |title=Avalon Casino Ballroom |publisher=Avalonball.com |accessdate=2009-06-21 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090701101606/http://avalonball.com/casino.asp |archivedate=2009-07-01 }} a famous landmark overlooking Avalon Harbor on [[Santa Catalina Island, California]], has never been used for traditional games of chance, which were already outlawed in California by the time it was built. The Copenhagen Casino was a theatre, known for the mass public meetings often held in its hall during the [[1848 Revolution]], which made Denmark a [[constitutional monarchy]]. Until 1937, it was a well-known Danish theatre.{{cite web |url= http://www.kb.dk/en/nb/samling/dra/dra-specialkataloger.html|title=Special catalogues in the Drama Collection |accessdate=2007-07-09 |work=The Royal Library }} The Hanko Casino in [[Hanko, Finland]]—one of that town's most conspicuous landmarks—was never used for gambling. Rather, it was a banquet hall for the [[Russian nobility]] which frequented this spa resort in the late 19th century and is now used as a restaurant.{{cite web|url=http://www.sailingshipadventures.com/DisplayPages/ItineraryPopUp.cfm?ItineraryID=2135 |title=Itinerary Details |publisher=''sailingshipadventures.com'' |accessdate=August 17, 2015 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20151123080936/http://www.sailingshipadventures.com/DisplayPages/ItineraryPopUp.cfm?ItineraryID=2135 |archivedate=November 23, 2015 }} In military and non-military usage in German and Spanish, a ''casino'' or ''kasino'' is an officers' [[mess]]. ==History of gambling houses== [[File:"Orient Saloon at Bisbee, Arizona... Faro game in full blast. Recognized, Left to right-Tony Downs (standing with derby) - NARA - 530986.tif|200px|thumb|Gambling at the Orient Saloon in [[Bisbee, Arizona]], {{circa}}1900. Photograph by [[C.S. Fly]].]] The precise origin of gambling is unknown. It is generally believed that gambling in some form or another has been seen in almost every society in history. From the Ancient [[Greeks]] and Romans to Napoleon's [[France]] and Elizabethan [[England]], much of history is filled with stories of entertainment based on games of chance. The first known European gambling house, not called a casino although meeting the modern definition, was the [[Ridotto]], established in [[Venice]], Italy in 1638 by the [[Great Council of Venice]] to provide controlled gambling during the carnival season. It was closed in 1774 as the city government felt it was impoverishing the local gentry.{{cite book|last1=Thomassen|first1=Bjørn|title=Liminality and the Modern: Living Through the In-Between|date=2014|publisher=Ashgate Publishing, Ltd.|page=160|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=5Sd7BAAAQBAJ&pg=PA160&lpg=PA160&dq=ridotto+1638+casino&source=bl&ots=ycf-bQdcM5&sig=sRJvGUBC40KsjX3kWOI19UYw7Bk&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0CEUQ6AEwB2oVChMIr-2H6IOxxwIVC9keCh18tAti#v=onepage&q=ridotto%201638%20casino&f=false|accessdate=August 17, 2015}} In American history, early gambling establishments were known as [[Western saloon|saloons]]. The creation and importance of saloons was greatly influenced by four major cities: [[New Orleans]], [[St. Louis]], [[Chicago]] and [[San Francisco]]. It was in the saloons that travelers could find people to talk to, drink with, and often gamble with. During the early 20th century in America, gambling became outlawed and banned by state legislation and social reformers of the time. However, in 1931, gambling was legalized throughout the state of [[Nevada]]. America's first legalized casinos were set up in those places. In 1976 [[New Jersey]] allowed gambling in [[Atlantic City]], now America's second largest gambling city. ==Gambling in casinos== [[File:Casino slots2.jpg|thumb|[[Slot machine]]s in Atlantic City. Slot machines are a standard attraction of casinos]] Most jurisdictions worldwide have a minimum [[gambling age]] (16 to 21 years of age in most countries which permit the operation of casinos).{{cite web| url=https://www.spotoncasinos.com/news/how-old-do-you-have-to-be-to-go-to-a-casino/| title=How Old Do You Have To Be To Go To A Casino? | accessdate=2018-04-07}} Customers gamble by playing [[casino game|games of chance]], in some cases with an element of skill, such as [[craps]], [[roulette]], [[baccarat (card game)|baccarat]], [[blackjack]], and [[video poker]]. Most games played have mathematically determined [[odds]] that ensure the house has at all times an overall advantage over the players. This can be expressed more precisely by the notion of [[expected value]], which is uniformly negative (from the player's perspective). This advantage is called the ''[[Casino game#House advantage|house edge]]''. In games such as [[poker]] where players play against each other, the house takes a commission called the [[Rake (poker)|rake]]. Casinos sometimes give out complimentary items or [[Comps (casino)|comps]] to gamblers. ''Payout'' is the percentage of funds ("winnings") returned to players. Casinos in the United States say that a player staking money won from the casino is ''playing with the house's money''. Video Lottery Machines (slot machines) have become one of the most popular forms of gambling in casinos. {{As of | 2011}} investigative reports have started calling into question whether the modern-day slot-machine is addictive. [http://www.cbsnews.com/stories/2011/01/07/60minutes/main7223329.shtml/ "Slot Machines: The Big Gamble"] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110713080253/http://www.cbsnews.com/stories/2011/01/07/60minutes/main7223329.shtml/ |date=July 13, 2011 }}, (Jan. 10, 2011). ''[[CBS 60 Minutes]]'', Retrieved 7/20/2011. {{Clear}} ==Design== Casino design—regarded as a psychological exercise—is an intricate process that involves optimising floor plan, décor and atmospherics to encourage gambling.[http://www.livecasino.co.uk/resource/casino-design/ Creating Compulsion: An Investigation Into Casino Design, Architecture and Ambience] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131104222350/http://www.livecasino.co.uk/resource/casino-design/ |date=November 4, 2013 }}, LiveCasino.co.uk, Retrieved 2/9/2013. Factors influencing gambling tendencies include sound, odour and lighting. Natasha Dow Schüll, an anthropologist at the [[Massachusetts Institute of Technology]], highlights the decision of the audio directors at Silicon Gaming to make its slot machines resonate in "the universally pleasant tone of C, sampling existing casino soundscapes to create a sound that would please but not clash".[https://www.theguardian.com/society/2013/jun/08/slot-machine-lose-lose-situation S] l [https://www.theguardian.com/society/2013/jun/08/slot-machine-lose-lose-situation ot machines: a lose lose situation] (June 8, 2013). ''[[www.theguardian.com|The Guardian]]'', Retrieved 2/9/2013. Dr Alan Hirsch, founder of the Smell & Taste Treatment and Research Foundation in Chicago, studied the impact of certain scents on gamblers, discerning that a pleasant albeit unidentifiable odour released by Las Vegas slot machines generated about 50% more in daily revenue. He suggested that the scent acted as an aphrodisiac, causing a more aggressive form of gambling."[http://www.timeoutchicago.com/things-to-do/casinos-gambling/14902383/the-psychology-behind-casino-design The psychology behind casino design] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130801080041/http://www.timeoutchicago.com/things-to-do/casinos-gambling/14902383/the-psychology-behind-casino-design |date=2013-08-01 }}", (August 24, 2011). ''[http://www.timeoutchicago.com/ Time Out Chicago] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130912001919/http://www.timeoutchicago.com/ |date=2013-09-12 }}'', Retrieved February 9, 2013. Casino designer [[Roger Thomas (designer)|Roger Thomas]] is credited with implementing a successful, disruptive design for the Las Vegas Wynn Resorts casinos in 2008. He broke casino design convention by introducing natural sunlight and flora to appeal to women. Thomas put in skylights and antique clocks, defying the commonplace notion that a casino should be a timeless space."[http://www.smartplanet.com/blog/design-architecture/how-disruptive-design-made-wynn-resorts-casinos-highly-profitable/5217 How disruptive design made Wynn Resorts' casinos highly profitable]", (March 26, 2012). [http://www.smartplanet.com/ Smart Planet], Retrieved 2/9/2013. ==Markets== The following lists major casino markets in the world with casino revenue of over US$1 billion as published in [[PricewaterhouseCoopers]]'s report on the outlook for the global casino market:http://www.pwc.com/gx/en/entertainment-media/pdf/pwc-playing-to-win.pdf ===By region=== {{Multiple issues|section=yes| {{Refimprove section|date=August 2018}} {{update section|date=August 2018}} }} {| class="wikitable sortable" |- ! rowspan="2"|Rank !! rowspan="2"|Region!! colspan="3"|Revenue (US$M){{Fix|text=out of date}} |- !2009!!2010
Projected!!2011
Projected |- | 1 || [[United States]]||57,240||56,500||58,030 |- | 2 || [[Asia]] [[Pacific]] ||21,845||32,305||41,259 |- | 3 || [[Europe]], [[Middle East]], [[Africa]]||17,259||16,186||16,452 |- | 4 || [[Canada]] ||3,712||3,835||4,045 |- | 5 || [[Latin America]] ||425||528||594 |- | || '''Total'''||'''100,481'''||'''109,354'''||'''120,380''' |} ===By markets=== {{Multiple issues|section=yes| {{Refimprove section|date=August 2018}} {{update section|date=August 2018}} }} {| class="wikitable sortable" |- ! rowspan="2"|Rank !! rowspan="2"|Location !!rowspan="2"| No. of
